name: Abhinav Srivastava
position: Founders' Office @ Bellatrix Aerospace | Space Tech | ex-DefTech | DeepTech Enthusiast
text: Some interesting points from Saanya Ojha on the conundrum that Intel seemingly faces.  Though I think there are some additional aspects to consider here given Pat Gelsinger's departure - though his legacy has been nothing short of legendary.  So, the question is what happened? What went wrong? A bunch of things (within and beyond Pat's control!):  While his efforts to revitalize Intel's manufacturing process through the 5N4Y initiative were noteworthy - but incomplete. To his credit, he recognized the "death spiral" the company faced as an IDM with a lagging fab. Catching up to TSMC was always going to be a Herculean task, and his focus there was understandable. However, that focus came at a cost.  The problem was just as much about what Gelsinger didn't do. While pouring energy into manufacturing, he neglected the product side. Intel missed the AI boom, lost data center market share, and failed to articulate a compelling product vision beyond a hopeful "AI PC super cycle."  Excellent at manufacturing - perhaps not so much at product.  Now, on to the present: There are recent leadership changes, with Michelle Johnston Holthaus taking the helm of the newly formed "Intel Products Group". This dedicated focus on product innovation is long overdue. But Holthaus has her work cut out for her. Can she, with CTO Greg Lavender, truly compete with the likes of Lisa Su and Mark Papermaster at AMD, or Jensen Huang at Nvidia? To be fair her background is in client CPUs ‚Äì a legacy strength, but is it enough in a world that is dominated by AI and accelerated computing?  I think Gelsinger's departure coupled with the existing structure of the "independent subsidiary inside of Intel" model for Foundry, makes a complete spin-off increasingly likely.  The recent 8-K filing referencing a hypothetical "Intel Foundry Corporation" within the government subsidies agreement suggests that such a move is being seriously considered. This separation would not only address the conflict of interest inherent in Foundry prioritizing its internal customer (Intel Products) but could also unlock value for both entities. It's worth noting that Gelsinger reportedly resisted this level of unbundling, making his departure potentially significant in this regard.  Does Intel come back? I don't know. It could quite quickly just turn into a case of Intel playing the laggard in an industry where product development is at breakneck pace and entities plan out things decades in advance. AMD is the ONLY company I can think of in that segment that has had a phoenix-like rise after stumbling over and over. Not sure if we can see Intel replicate that.  P.S. In case you didn't know: The Intel board has officially unbundled ‚ÄúIntel [the IDM]‚Äù into two divisions: a fabless design group (Products) and a fab (Foundry).  (Link to the Form 8K in the comments)

name: Chris Schlebusch
position: 'Where' is a culture, not a subscription.
text: I would've loved to see some mention of large scale semiconductor manufacturing incentives. In simple terms a TSMC-style fab in Oz. Think of all the world leading skills and trades needed to build it, then operate it, and what the flow-on would be from a long term education planning perspective. That alone would be more valuable than the plant itself, in my opinion. It's as if there is no-one in government that can dream big enough with enough understanding of what it means. World leading coordinated education and high-tech-high-volume-high-margin manufacturing is (too?) complicated. Am I too critical/naive and are there real reasons why this shouldn't be an aspirational goal? It's not a cheap labour thing - don't start with that argument. They got a TSMC fab off the ground in Arizona, Intel runs fabs in Israel, and ASML is Dutch. Why can't we get something like it too? Is it an AUKUS thing?

name: Bla≈æej Bucha
position: Scientific Researcher at Slovak University of Technology
text: Spherical harmonic transforms on distributed-memory systems using MPI  In CHarm, spherical harmonic synthesis/analysis of point data can now also be conducted on systems with distributed memory. These could be, for instance, nodes of high-performance computing clusters or a few ordinary PCs interconnected via some network protocol (e.g., SSH). MPI makes it possible to distribute spherical harmonic coefficients and the signal to be analyzed/synthesized among a number of independent shared-memory systems that can communicate together. As a result, it is now fairly possible to perform spherical harmonic transforms up to degrees as high as 100,000 and beyond. This allows us, for instance, to model the Earth's topography at 200-m spatial resolution and higher with .  CHarm now combines three parallelization techniques. Within a single CPU, CHarm takes advantage of CPU instructions (AVX, AVX2, AVX-512, NEON). On shared-memory systems (e.g., multicore CPUs), the parallelization is done by . Finally, on distributed-memory systems (e.g., HPC clusters), parallelization is now supported.  CHarm is a C/Python library for high-degree spherical harmonic transforms mainly focused on (but not limited to) modelling.  Source code: Documentation: Cookbook-style examples: New benchmarks (no MPI):  In case you too enjoy talking about spherical harmonics, meet me at my poster G33B-3381 at in Washington, D.C., on Wednesday, 11 December 2024.  The development of CHarm is being funded by the EU through the .

position: Senior Analyst Programmer - autore di ChatGPT e Oltre Strategie Avanzate con RAGEP
text: ùêàùêßùê≠ùêûùê• ùêöùê¨ùê¨ùêÆùê¶ùêû: ùêúùêûùê´ùêúùêöùê¨ùê¢ ùêÇùêÑùêé ùêúùê®ùêß ùêßùêûùê´ùêØùê¢ ùêù‚Äôùêöùêúùêúùê¢ùêöùê¢ùê® ùêû ùêúùêÆùê®ùê´ùêû ùêùùê¢ ùê¨ùê¢ùê•ùê¢ùêúùê¢ùê®  Quando Pat Gelsinger, storico CEO di Intel, ha annunciato le sue dimissioni, una domanda ha iniziato a rimbalzare tra i corridoi di Santa Clara: "Chi prender√† ora il volante di questa macchina senza freni chiamata Intel?"  ùëºùíè ùíÇùíèùíèùíñùíèùíÑùíäùíê ùíÖùíä ùíçùíÇùíóùíêùíìùíê ùíÖùíÇ ùíîùíêùíàùíèùíê La posizione √® aperta e, a quanto pare, disperatamente vacante. L‚Äôazienda, leader nei semiconduttori, cerca un CEO che abbia almeno queste competenze:  1. Gestione del caos: il candidato ideale deve essere in grado di navigare tra competitor agguerriti come AMD e Nvidia, evitando al contempo di perdere terreno contro giganti asiatici come TSMC e Samsung.  2. Visione strategica: non solo per i chip futuri, ma anche per individuare quali business vendere quando tutto va storto.  3. Immune allo stress: resistere al bombardamento di critiche e aspettative irrealistiche mentre si cerca di recuperare il terreno perduto.  4. Creativit√† contabile: fare miracoli con finanziamenti inferiori alle aspettative e risultati trimestrali altalenanti.  ùë∞ùíèùíïùíÜùíç ùë≠ùíêùíñùíèùíÖùíìùíö ùíÜ ùíä ùíîùíêùíàùíèùíä ùíèùíÜùíç ùíÑùíÇùíîùíîùíÜùíïùíïùíê Il nuovo CEO avr√† l‚Äôonore e l‚Äôonere di capire cosa fare dell‚ÄôIntel Foundry. Nonostante grandi promesse, i ricavi significativi non si sono ancora visti. Forse basterebbe un cartello con scritto: "Fabbrica disponibile per matrimoni e eventi."  ùë™ùíâùíä ùíîùíä ùíÜÃÄ ùíàùíäùíÇÃÄ ùíÑùíÇùíèùíÖùíäùíÖùíÇùíïùíê Voci di corridoio suggeriscono che tra i primi CV arrivati ci siano nomi improbabili:  - ChatGPT, che promette di usare AI per risolvere ogni problema (tranne i ritardi di produzione). - Elon Musk, che probabilmente trasformer√† Intel in un‚Äôazienda che produce chip per Marte. - Un Raspberry Pi, perch√© almeno "non costa quanto uno stipendio da CEO".  ùëºùíèùíÇ ùíÑùíìùíäùíîùíä‚Ä¶ ùíáùíÜùíîùíïùíäùíóùíÇ L'annuncio delle dimissioni √® arrivato proprio a ridosso del weekend del Ringraziamento. Probabilmente, durante il pranzo, Gelsinger avr√† pensato: "Tra tacchini e semiconduttori, preferisco i primi".  ùë∞ùíç ùíáùíñùíïùíñùíìùíê ùíÖùíä ùë∞ùíèùíïùíÜùíç? Tra riorganizzazioni, tagli, competizione e innovazioni mancate, Intel si trova nel mezzo di una crisi esistenziale. Ma chi lo sa? Forse il prossimo CEO sar√† proprio uno di noi, armato di un PowerPoint pieno di slide convincenti e di un cuore di silicio.  Intel, il posto perfetto per chi ama le sfide impossibili. Se vi sentite all‚Äôaltezza, il consiglio d‚Äôamministrazione vi aspetta. Ma attenzione: il colloquio potrebbe essere pi√π difficile che risolvere il bug di un processore Pentium degli anni ‚Äô90.

Proizvodnje procesorjev namreƒç ni veƒç uspela ustrezno posodobiti, kar je vplivalo na energijsko uƒçinkovitost in konkurenƒçnost procesorjev, zamude pa so se (medtem ko so TSMC in ostali hiteli naprej) samo ≈°e nalagale. Zdaj je veliko vpra≈°anje, kaj lahko stori njegov naslednik (kdorkoli ≈æe bo), in koliko mo≈ænosti sploh ≈°e ima Intel v taki obliki in obsegu.

name: KST Components Limited
text: In the third quarter of 2024, global foundry industry revenue increased by 27% year-on-year and 11% quarter-on-quarter. TSMC has a market share of 64%.  TSMC's third quarter performance in 2024 was strong, with strong gross margins exceeding expectations. This success was mainly due to the high utilization of its cutting-edge nodes, including N5 and N3, which benefited from the demand for AI accelerators and the strong seasonality of smartphones. The company expanded its industry revenue share to 64% in the third quarter from 62% in the previous quarter. TSMC expects AI-related demand to grow significantly in the next few years, and AI servers already account for a dozen of its revenue in 2024. The company expects this AI revenue share to grow further in the future as cloud service providers continue to adopt more and practical AI applications emerge. Although the company has announced that it will at least double its CoWoS capacity in 2025, it is still not enough to meet customers' strong demand for AI. In the non-AI semiconductor market, despite continued weak demand, TSMC expects a steady recovery from 2025, alleviating concerns that the semiconductor cycle may have peaked.  Samsung Foundry's revenue increased slightly quarter-on-quarter, mainly due to weaker-than-expected seasonal demand for Android smartphones. However, the company still maintained its second position with a 12% market share in the third quarter of 2024. Samsung Foundry is advancing its 2nm GAA process with the goal of achieving mass production by 2025, focusing on optimizing performance, power and area (PPA) for mobile, HPC, AI and automotive applications. The company is also working with customers to develop advanced 2.5D and 3D packaging solutions to ensure the competitiveness of its 2nm platform through continuous innovation.  SMIC's third quarter 2024 results were strong, with the company reporting strong revenue growth driven by recovering demand for consumer electronics, smartphones and IoT applications. The company's 12-inch wafer shipments increased significantly thanks to an improved product mix and higher average selling prices. SMIC's overall utilization rate rose to 90.4%, reflecting continued strong demand, especially at 28nm, 40nm and 65nm nodes. Although fourth-quarter guidance remains conservative due to expected seasonal weakness, the company remains optimistic about its annual growth prospects, thanks to its focus on leveraging domestic demand and localization efforts.

name: Kakuba Gerald
position: Hardware Design Engineer at Silicon Mechanics
text: I strongly assure everyone reading this that any country accepting the U.S.'s propaganda to restrict its companies from shipping products to Chinese firms will regret it within 15 years.  This strategy mirrors the historical "divide and rule" tactic used in Africa. The U.S. aims to consolidate global manufacturing within its territory. Once that goal is achieved, it will impose unfavorable tariffs or push foreign companies out entirely.  By then, these countries will lack viable alternatives. The U.S. will have become significantly stronger, overtaking them in areas where they once excelled. These nations will lose their leverage in negotiations, effectively surrendering their autonomy.  The U.S. strategy is clear: attract companies with cutting-edge technology, like TSMC, ASML, Samsung, and others, to establish branches in the U.S. Over time, these companies will be compelled to prioritize investment and R&D in their U.S.-based campuses. Eventually, their home branches, once proud headquarters, will become mere shadows of their former selves‚Äîinferior to their U.S. counterparts.  When this happens, these nations‚ÄîJapan, the Netherlands, South Korea, the UK, and others‚Äîwill lose their place at the global negotiating table. They will realize, too late, that they were used as pawns.  My advice to countries with technological assets that the U.S. relies on:  Recognize that these technologies are your leverage, your gold‚Äîprotect them fiercely.  Avoid taking sides. Stay neutral and maintain your autonomy.  Continue supplying products to all markets, resisting pressure to align with the U.S.'s sanction schemes.   Short-term alignment with the U.S. might seem strategically sound now because their companies are still catching up. However, once the U.S. firms gain dominance, the alliance will lose its value, leaving partner nations at a severe disadvantage.  Remaining neutral secures long-term benefits, sovereignty, and power as an independent nation.

text: üö® Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger Steps Down Amid Major Shifts üö®  After over three years of transformative leadership, Pat Gelsinger has retired as Intel's CEO, leaving the tech giant at a critical juncture. His tenure aimed to restore Intel‚Äôs dominance, backed by a $100 billion U.S. expansion and $7.9 billion in CHIPS Act subsidies.  1- Challenges under his leadership:  üìâ Intel‚Äôs stock value plummeted by 61%  ‚õî The company was ousted from the Dow Jones, replaced by NVIDIA  ‚úÇÔ∏è 15,000 job cuts and delays in global chipmaking projects  üìä Competition from TSMC, Samsung, and Nvidia in the AI and semiconductor space  üìâ A 50% drop in Intel's stock value this year   2- Post-announcement impact:  üìà Stock Rebound: Intel's shares surged nearly 6% following the announcement, reflecting renewed investor optimism.  üíº Interim Leadership: CFO David Zinsner and Intel Products Chief Michelle Johnston Holthaus will lead temporarily as Intel seeks a visionary new CEO.  üåü Industry Impact: Rival stocks like NVIDIA also saw gains, highlighting the shifting dynamics in the competitive semiconductor landscape.  Intel‚Äôs turnaround hinges on rebuilding trust and fostering innovation while navigating a complex restructuring process amid declining demand and rapidly shifting market conditions.

His tenure aimed to restore Intel‚Äôs dominance, backed by a $100 billion U.S. expansion and $7.9 billion in CHIPS Act subsidies.  1- Challenges under his leadership:  üìâ Intel‚Äôs stock value plummeted by 61%  ‚õî The company was ousted from the Dow Jones, replaced by NVIDIA  ‚úÇÔ∏è 15,000 job cuts and delays in global chipmaking projects  üìä Competition from TSMC, Samsung, and Nvidia in the AI and semiconductor space  üìâ A 50% drop in Intel's stock value this year   2- Post-announcement impact:  üìà Stock Rebound: Intel's shares surged nearly 6% following the announcement, reflecting renewed investor optimism.  üíº Interim Leadership: CFO David Zinsner and Intel Products Chief Michelle Johnston Holthaus will lead temporarily as Intel seeks a visionary new CEO.  üåü Industry Impact: Rival stocks like NVIDIA also saw gains, highlighting the shifting dynamics in the competitive semiconductor landscape.  Intel‚Äôs turnaround hinges on rebuilding trust and fostering innovation while navigating a complex restructuring process amid declining demand and rapidly shifting market conditions.

name: Anvitha Giddaluru
position: Advanced VLSI Design and Verification Trainee at Maven Silicon | 2024 graduate | Seeking for job/Internship in RTL Design and Verification in semiconductor industry
text: hashtag #100DaysofRTL  Hello all,  üöÄ Day [21] of üöÄ  1_8 Demux by using 1_4 demux  Today, I delved into designing a 1-to-8 Demux using 1-to-4 Demux modules in Verilog. This approach highlights the beauty of modular design, where we break down complex circuits into reusable and manageable components. üí° üîß How it works: A 1-to-4 Demux first splits the input based on the 2 MSBs of the select line. Two additional 1-to-4 Demuxes further distribute the output to 8 lines, controlled by the LSB of the select line. This hierarchical structure keeps the design clean and scalable! üöÄ üîë Key Learnings: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Modular design makes verification and debugging much easier. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Building large circuits from smaller blocks enhances scalability. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Hierarchical approaches are highly efficient for FPGA synthesis.  ‚ú® Applications: üí† Routing signals in multi-line communication systems. üí† Enabling specific devices in memory-mapped systems. üí† Managing outputs in control systems.  üëâ check my github repo for the verilog code:  üëâ Hope you learnt something today

text: ‚ÄúWe are entering the AI Era and Taiwan is at the centre of it!‚Äù These words from ASM CEO Hichem M'Saad marked the grand opening of their new Hsinchu, Taiwan office today. The celebration included many local customs, such as the white radish (Â•ΩÂΩ©È†≠) and pineapple (Êó∫‰æÜ), both expressing the best of luck for the new offices and its employees.  ASM‚Äôs presence in Taiwan dates back 19 years, starting with just a handful of employees. Since then, the company‚Äôs constant growth is testament to the confidence of the global semiconductor industry in ASM‚Äôs technological breakthroughs in ALD, vertical furnaces and Si/SiC epitaxy platforms. Now, the Hsinchu building will be the new ‚ÄòASM home‚Äô for more than 450 service engineers, sales managers and customer services.  And with everything that is ‚Äúahead of what‚Äôs next‚Äù that number is expected to grow significantly. The tools and process technologies developed by ASM enables chip manufacturers in Taiwan to make the most leading edge IC‚Äôs. With 2nm chips being the preferred node for AI and TSMC‚Äôs announcement to start 2nm production in Hsinchu next year,will be just as much central to the AI Era. This was also reflected in the words of proud customer, who recognised ASM with the TSMC Excellent Performance Award for the fifth consecutive year: ‚ÄúASM is key to the ambition of TSMC to keep delivering the most advanced chips. The ASM-TSMC partnership is now moving to the 2nm node and will continue to exist once we move into the angstrom era!‚Äù

name: Sandra Crouse
position: Abachy.com Semiconductor Business Directory and Marketplace, Marketing Manager.
text: The evolution of computing capacity has consistently increased over time, with significant shifts in integrated circuit architectures from GPUs to ASICs, reflecting a transition marked by advancements like NVIDIA's Hopper architecture optimized for AI applications. Intel, once a leader in the semiconductor industry, ceded its dominance to NVIDIA as it struggled to meet the demands of deep learning due to the superior parallel processing capabilities of GPUs.  Moore's Law, which is frequently misinterpreted as a strict doubling of transistor density every 18 months, actually encompasses broader metrics such as computational speed and storage density that drive consumer technology. This understanding shifts the focus from transistor counts to the practical benefits of computational power and efficiency, framing Moore's observations as part of a significant long-term trend in technological advancement.  As industries increasingly rely on exponential improvements in computational power driven by Moore‚Äôs Law, transformative changes are expected across various sectors, including drug discovery, agriculture, and automotive technology. This accelerating pace of change not only fuels entrepreneurship and innovation but also highlights the economic significance of continued advancements in semiconductor technology, ultimately reshaping how businesses operate and compete in a data-driven economy. name: TechSoda
text: Speculation about Pat Gelsinger's departure had been brewing, particularly as Intel Corporation faced mounting pressure to deliver on its CHIPS Act commitments to create jobs and expand production. While Intel desperately needed the government funding, its foundry business posted heavy quarterly losses. To manage costs, Gelsinger initiated layoffs and outsourced advanced chip production to , so that they could be in time for market and compete with rivals such as and . However, he had no choice, because if Intel‚Äôs products fail to hit the shelves on time, it will lose even more market share to rivals. That is a vicious cycle that the genius engineer Gelsinger did not figure out during his tenure. This move underscored a fact hard to swallow: Intel lacked competitiveness, forcing reliance on external manufacturing to maintain market schedules and avoid further erosion of its market share.  Despite acquiring ‚Äôs cutting-edge lithography machines earlier than its rivals, Intel struggled to achieve satisfactory yields, exacerbating financial pressure from depreciation costs and declining sales. This misstep highlighted a critical misjudgment: Intel's strength now lies in product design and marketing, not manufacturing.   Read the commentary:

text: The co-leader of the Department of Government Efficiency has labeled the subsidies under the U.S. CHIPS Act as ‚Äúwasteful,‚Äù raising concerns about the Biden administration's funding strategy prior to the upcoming transition in leadership.  Despite ongoing discussions with South Korean companies like Samsung and SK hynix, these firms have not yet received any subsidies, while the Biden administration has finalized over $16 billion in funding for various companies, including TSMC, GlobalFoundries, and Intel.  The DOGE co-leader plans to conduct a thorough review of all contracts issued under the CHIPS Act, as well as other fiscal measures from the Biden administration, and has proposed that the Inspector General closely examine these expenditures.

name: Harsha vardhan Nune
position: ASIC physical design intern @at SiMax tech.
text: The process of making silicon from sand involves several steps, including:  *Collecting sand: Chip manufacturers use high-purity silica sand, which is about 95% silicon dioxide.  *Heating the sand: Carbon is added to the sand and heated in a furnace, which bonds the carbon with the sand's oxygen to create carbon dioxide and release 99% pure silicon.  *Extracting silicon crystal:  Individual silicon crystals are extracted before making wafers and chips. Chemical purification Metallurgical grade silicon is exposed to hydrogen chloride gas to react with impurities and form compounds that can be removed. This process results in semiconductor grade silicon with 99.99999% purity.  *Growing silicon crystal:  The Czochralski process is a common method for growing silicon crystals. In this process, a silicon or germanium seed crystal is heated and dipped into molten silicon, where it gradually solidifies around it to form a cylindrical crystal.  *Slicing and polishing:   The crystal is sliced into thin, flat discs using a diamond saw, and then polished to remove any surface defects and impurities.

name: Martin Strnad
position: Game design, narrative and production consultant with proven track record of 16 years in game dev and over 40 mil in sales of projects I participated on.
text: Pat Gelsinger steps down from his role as CEO at Intel. Just like in politics, it is hard to take charge of a big company after previous years of mismanagement. So, no matter how easy it would be to point out his failures with the last three generations of Intel's CPUs and the too-slow rollout of Intel's dedicated GPUs in the face of much faster-moving competition from AMD and Nvidia, let's focus on what he managed to do right.  Intel is currently the only company capable of chip manufacturing that has the ASML machines able to produce chips at sub-3nm scale in their most recent chip factories on U.S. soil. Yes, TSMC will apparently soon receive them as well, but the head start Intel managed to get in constructing new chip fabs under Gelsinger's leadership has the potential to bring advanced chip production back to the West, which may prove to be very crucial in the current difficult geopolitical climate.  Intel's dedicated GPUs mentioned above may have had a slow rollout and took much longer than originally planned, but this was a step in the right direction. The more competition we have in this very difficult field, the better it is for the whole market. Both end customers, aka gamers, and companies running large AI data centers will eventually benefit from having multiple options when it comes to hardware.  Whoever comes next to fill the CEO role at Intel will greatly benefit from both of these advances made during Gelsinger's tenure at Intel. And no matter how catastrophic all this looks for the Western technology industry, it makes zero sense for the U.S. government to let this tech giant fall. So my last statement is: keep watching the dip, it may take a few years, but Intel will eventually recover.

name: Zhiyuan Chen
position: R&D Center Manager | Hon Hai Precision Industry | Technology Innovation and Product Development Leader
text: Kissinger "retired" reveals the worst-case scenario: Trump increases semiconductor tariffs to save Intel Intel, a major processor manufacturer, suddenly announced on the 2nd that CEO Pat Gelsinger had retired and resigned on the 1st, and also resigned from the board of directors. It was reported that the board of directors believed that Gelsinger's transformation plan was not effective, so it requested Choose "Retire" or "Dismissed". But Lu Xingzhi, a well-known semiconductor analyst, believes that the focus now is who the board of directors should find to take over Intel? But the last thing he wants is to see Trump significantly increase tariffs on non-U.S. semiconductor manufacturing to more than 50% in order to save Intel.  Since taking over as CEO of Intel in 2021, Kissinger has proposed a four-year revitalization plan in an attempt to reverse the predicament, but the strategy has not worked. During his tenure, Intel's market value has shrunk significantly and is now only one-thirtieth of Nvidia, which focuses on artificial intelligence chips.  According to Reuters, people familiar with the matter revealed that at last week's Intel board meeting, it was felt that Jissinger's costly transformation plan was progressing slowly and was ineffective, so he was asked to choose "retirement" or "dismissal." Ge finally chose to retire.  Semiconductor analyst Lu Xingzhi analyzed on Facebook that Ji Xingji originally signed a contract for five years, but ended up packing up and leaving after three years. Was it because the board of directors forced him to retire early before his term was completed? Or are you disappointed and leaving your job because you are trapped in a tight trap that cannot be 100% divided and create cancer? He believes that Kissinji has been not favored not long after taking office, waiting to see when he will be "let go" (fired).  Lu Xingzhi further pointed out the contradictory strategies proposed by Ji Xingji, such as finding TSMC to manufacture advanced manufacturing processes, but saying all day long that Taiwan's geopolitics is dangerous; he also vigorously developed wafer foundry and expanded production everywhere to obtain subsidies, which resulted in Intel's collapse. The losses are getting bigger and bigger, and they are out of control.  Lu Xingzhi even mentioned that Ji Xingji set an unachievable goal of five nodes in four years. As a result, where will the 20A/18A process be in 2024? The AI GPU cannot be designed, the AI ASIC Claude is sold in low numbers, the new computer CPU has a lot of problems, the server CPU keeps losing share, some of the laid off employees were immediately hired, and the stories are too numerous to list.

name: Eddy T
text: üî∑ Will Moore‚Äôs Law Continue to Develop? A Hot Topic in the Semiconductor Industry  initially predicted that the number of transistors would double every two years, accompanied by improved performance and reduced costs. However, as process technology approaches physical limits, Moore‚Äôs Law faces increasing challenges.  üî∏ Challenges:  ‚ñ™Ô∏è Process Limits: As technology advances to 2nm nodes and beyond, physical limitations such as quantum effects, leakage currents, and heat dissipation issues are becoming increasingly difficult to overcome.  ‚ñ™Ô∏è Rising Costs: Semiconductor manufacturing equipment and design costs have surged with node scaling, making the economic benefits of Moore‚Äôs Law less pronounced than before.  ‚ñ™Ô∏è Technological Bottlenecks: While new materials (e.g., silicon carbide, gallium nitride) and technologies (e.g., 3D packaging, chiplets) offer breakthroughs in performance and efficiency, they no longer solely rely on increasing transistor density.  üî∏ Possibilities for Continuation:  ‚ñ™Ô∏è Innovative Architectures: Improvements in chip design architectures, such as , , and specialized accelerators, allow the spirit of Moore‚Äôs Law to persist in new forms‚Äîfocusing more on performance enhancements rather than just increasing transistor density.  ‚ñ™Ô∏è 3D ICs and Advanced Packaging: The focus of innovation is shifting from process scaling to vertical integration (e.g., ‚Äôs and ‚Äôs ). This approach not only boosts performance but also extends the economic benefits of Moore‚Äôs Law.  ‚ñ™Ô∏è Quantum Computing and Emerging Technologies: Although not yet fully mature, technologies such as quantum computing and photonic computing may transcend the limitations of traditional semiconductors, paving new paths for Moore‚Äôs Law.  While the continuation of Moore‚Äôs Law in its traditional sense may become increasingly difficult, its spirit‚Äîenhancing performance and reducing costs‚Äîwill likely endure in new technological forms and innovative architectures. The future of Moore‚Äôs Law will depend more on the synergy of material science, , computational architectures, and emerging technologies rather than solely on transistor scaling. However, future risks exist if the Dutch government aligns its policies with the US on exports of lithography equipment to China. ‚ô¶ AMEC, NAURA and other Chinese semiconductor tool manufacturers face direct blacklisting, further isolating them from global supply chains. name: Sinan Othman, Ph.D.
text: Intel Corp. Chief Executive Officer Pat Gelsinger was forced out after the board lost confidence in his plans to turn around the iconic chipmaker, adding to turmoil at one of the pioneers of the technology industry.  The clash came to a head last week when Gelsinger met with the board about the company‚Äôs progress on winning back market share and narrowing the gap with Nvidia Corp., according to people familiar with the matter. He was given the option to retire or be removed, and chose to announce the end of his career at Intel, said the people, who asked not to be identified because the proceedings weren‚Äôt made public.  Intel Chief Financial Officer David Zinsner and Executive Vice President Michelle Johnston Holthaus are serving as interim co-CEOs while the board searches for Gelsinger‚Äôs replacement, the company said in a statement. Frank Yeary, independent chair of the board of Intel, will serve as interim executive chair.  Gelsinger, 63, was once hailed as a savior of the chip giant. After taking the reins three years ago, he professed his love for the company and said he was determined to restore it to preeminence in the semiconductor industry. The executive first began working at Intel when he was a teenager but left in 2009 and became CEO of VMware Inc. Upon returning in 2021, he promised to regain the chipmaker‚Äôs lead in manufacturing ‚Äî something it had lost to rivals like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.  Gelsinger couldn‚Äôt immediately be reached for comment.  Intel investors, eager to see changes at the company, applauded the CEO‚Äôs departure. The shares gained as much as 6% in New York on Monday, though they remain down about 50% this year.  Gelsinger set out to take Intel beyond its traditional strength in personal computer and server processors by expanding into making chips for other companies ‚Äî something it had never done before and putting it into direct competition with TSMC and Samsung Electronics Co. As part of his revival strategy, Gelsinger laid out a costly plan to expand Intel‚Äôs factory network. That included building a massive new complex in Ohio, a project for which the company received federal aid from the Chips and Science Act.  Whoever replaces Gelsinger will face the same set of problems he was brought in to fix, including the fallout from poor decisions made by his predecessors. What would have once been the most desirable job in the $500 billion chip industry has become a nearly untenable position. The next CEO has to take on competitors with greater resources and catch up in AI computing, all while showing that Intel can be the groundbreaking company it once was.  Finding someone to take that hot seat may not be easy. Before Gelsinger was appointed to replace CEO Bob Swan, there was speculation that a number of prominent executives were possible candidates. Many on Wall Street proposed approaching Advanced Micro Devices Inc.‚Äôs Lisa Su for the job. [...]

name: Armand Jacobs
position: üîß Business Manager / Manager Engineering: VIRO Echt B.V.
text: Intel CEO Gelsinger moet opstappen Bestuur verloor vertrouwen in turnaround plan  Saemvatting - Gelsinger vertrekt voordat Intel's turnaround-plan is voltooid - De aandelen van Intel dalen met 0,5%; Het is dit jaar met de helft gedaald - Communicatiechef is van plan het bedrijf te verlaten, zeggen bronnen - Zinsner en Holthaus benoemd tot interim co-CEO's tijdens CEO-zoektocht - CEO was begonnen met een turnaround-plan van ontslagen, verkoop van activa  Intel Chief Executive Pat Gelsinger is gedwongen te vertrekken minder dan vier jaar nadat hij het roer van het bedrijf heeft overgenomen en de controle heeft overgedragen aan twee luitenants terwijl het haperende Amerikaanse chipmaking-icoon op zoek is naar een permanente vervanger. Gelsinger, die op 1 december ontslag nam, vertrok na een bestuursvergadering vorige week waarin directeuren vonden dat het kostbare en ambitieuze plan van Gelsinger om Intel om te draaien niet werkte en dat de voortgang van de verandering niet snel genoeg was, volgens een persoon die bekend is met de zaak. Het bestuur vertelde Gelsinger dat hij met pensioen kon gaan of verwijderd kon worden, en hij koos ervoor om af te treden, aldus de bron.  Zijn vertrek komt ruim voor de voltooiing van zijn vierjarige routekaart om de voorsprong van het bedrijf in het maken van de snelste en kleinste computerchips te herstellen, een kroon die het verloor aan TSMC, die chips maakt voor Intel-rivalen zoals Nvidia. Onder Gelsinger is Intel, dat in 1968 werd opgericht en decennialang de basis vormde van de wereldwijde dominantie van Silicon Valley op het gebied van chips, verschrompeld tot een marktwaarde die meer dan 30 keer kleiner is dan Nvidia, de leider op het gebied van kunstmatige-intelligentiechips.  Gelsinger erfde in 2021 een bedrijf vol uitdagingen die hij verergerde. Intel stelde hoge ambities voor productie- en AI-capaciteiten bij grote klanten, maar verloor of annuleerde uiteindelijk contracten onder zijn toezicht en was niet in staat om de beloofde goederen te leveren, volgens een speciaal rapport van Reuters in oktober. Hij deed optimistische beweringen over toekomstige AI-chipdeals die Intels eigen schattingen overtroffen, waardoor het bedrijf ongeveer een maand geleden een recente omzetprognose schrapte.  Bloomberg berichtte eerder over de omstandigheden rond de pensionering van Gelsinger. Gelsinger, 63, heeft zowel investeerders als Amerikaanse functionarissen, die de ommekeer van Intel subsidi√´ren, verzekerd dat zijn productieplannen op schema blijven. Maar de volledige resultaten zullen pas volgend jaar bekend zijn, wanneer het bedrijf ernaar streeft een vlaggenschip-laptopchip terug in zijn eigen fabrieken te brengen.

text: üîç TSMC's 2nm Process Set to Revolutionize the Semiconductor Industry - Coming to the US in 2028 ?  üîπ TSMC is accelerating its path to advanced chip production with its 2-nanometer (2nm) process, a leap beyond the current 3nm technology. üîπ TSMC is set to begin mass production in Taiwan in 2025, with commercial production slated to start in the U.S. by 2028. üîπ TSMC is constructing advanced fabs in Arizona, including one that will soon produce chips using the 2nm process. This expansion is part of TSMC's $65B investment in the U.S., further strengthening its position as a global leader in semiconductor technology. üîπ Why does this matter? The 2nm process will power the next wave of AI, smart devices, and high-performance computing.

name: Kumar Priyadarshi
position: Building TechoVedas | Global Foundries | NUS | IITB | IISER
text: 5 Reasons why Semiconductor Industry is Hard to Crack:  üöÄ Intense Capital Investment:   Building a new semiconductor fabrication plant (fab) can cost tens of billions of dollars.  Example: TSMC's new fab in Arizona is estimated to cost over $40 billion.  The extreme precision required in semiconductor manufacturing necessitates cleanroom environments and specialized equipment, significantly driving up costs.  üöÄ Semiconductor fabrication plant (fab)  Moore's Law, which states that the number of transistors in a dense integrated circuit doubles approximately every two years, 1 continues to drive rapid innovation.  Example: The transition from 7nm to 5nm and now 3nm process nodes requires significant R&D investments and technological breakthroughs.  The relentless pace of technological advancement forces chipmakers to constantly invest in research and development to stay competitive.  üöÄ Complex Manufacturing Process:  Semiconductor manufacturing involves hundreds of steps, each with a low margin of error.  Example: Photolithography, a critical step in chipmaking, requires precise alignment of masks to create intricate circuit patterns.  The intricate and delicate nature of the manufacturing process necessitates highly skilled workers, advanced equipment, and stringent quality control measures.  üöÄ Semiconductor manufacturing process  Semiconductor chips are manufactured in a global supply chain involving multiple countries and regions.  Example: A single chip may involve components sourced from the US, Europe, Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan.  The complex and interconnected nature of the global supply chain makes it vulnerable to geopolitical tensions, trade disputes, and natural disasters, which can disrupt production and increase costs.  üöÄ Highly Skilled Workforce:  Semiconductor engineers and technicians require years of specialized training and education.  Example: A semiconductor engineer may need a PhD in electrical engineering or materials science.  The demand for highly skilled workers in the semiconductor industry often exceeds supply, making it challenging to attract and retain top talent. text: In May 2023, an accident at TSMC's Arizona plant that resulted in the death of a worker sparked a six-month investigation by the Arizona Department of Occupational Safety and Health. The findings show that has failed to completely eliminate safety hazards that could lead to death or serious injury. On November 7, TSMC was fined $16,131, an important warning for the Asian company to adapt to U.S. safety regulations. At the same time, is also facing a lawsuit over alleged discrimination against Asians in the hiring process. These incidents have not only raised questions about TSMC's success in transplanting its local management culture, but also reflected the difficulties of the company's cross-cultural operations. However, the U.S. Department of Commerce remains confident in TSMC's ability to adapt, approving $6.6 billion in subsidies under the Act and plans to release at least $1 billion in 2024. name: LaoBing ZH
text: # Insights from the Departing White House Chief Tech Advisor on AI  As the Biden administration winds down, Arati Prabhakar, Director of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP), shared her perspectives on artificial intelligence (AI) in a recent interview with *MIT Technology Review*. Here are the key points:  ## The Dual Nature of AI  Prabhakar highlighted both the achievements and risks of AI, such as deepfakes and gender-based violence. She has worked with the Gender Policy Council to promote industry accountability, though legislative solutions are still in progress. Concerns about AI chatbots have emerged as a more immediate threat compared to bioweapons.  ## Trust in Government Institutions  Building public trust in AI tools is crucial, especially in national security and law enforcement. Prabhakar emphasized the need for responsible use of technologies like facial recognition to ensure privacy and security.  ## Immigration Policy and Talent  She stressed that immigration policy plays a vital role in attracting global talent to the U.S. AI sector, warning that current political dynamics could hinder this effort.  ## Optimism About the CHIPS Act  Prabhakar expressed optimism regarding the CHIPS Act, which aims to boost U.S. semiconductor manufacturing. Investments from companies like Intel and TSMC indicate a positive shift toward domestic production.  ## Restoring Trust in Science  Finally, she noted the importance of restoring public trust in science, particularly given disparities in health outcomes. Greater transparency and accountability from the scientific community are essential.  ## Conclusion  Prabhakar's insights highlight the need for accountability, responsible technology use, and inclusive talent policies as we navigate an AI-driven future. With thoughtful leadership, AI can serve as a positive force for society.

name: AHMED ELSHABSHIRY
text: Today (29) is the last trading day of November for Taiwan stocks, and with the arrival of December, this year will also come to an end. Various local investment advisors have also released their outlooks for Taiwan stocks in 2025 at the end of this month, and most of them are optimistic that Taiwan stocks will challenge new highs next year, with Monte Jade and CITIC giving the highest high of 27,500 points.  Regarding the outlook for 2025, all the investment advisors believe that the profits of Taiwan's listed companies and Taiwan's GDP are expected to continue to grow, which is expected to further boost the weighted index, and each advisor predicts that Taiwan stocks will reach a high of 25,000 to 27,500 points next year. However, it is still necessary to pay attention to the policies introduced by Donald Trump after his inauguration, which may affect the stock market due to political and economic uncertainties. If there is a pullback, the lows predicted by various investment advisors are around 20,000~21,500 points, and there will be a strong support near the annual line, which is considered by the advisors to be a good opportunity to lay out the market on the low side.  Cathay United Bank's chief economist Lin Kai-chiu believes that next year will be a year of ‚Äúchaos and prosperity‚Äù, considering Trump's possible immigration and tariff policies, which will lead to a ‚Äúchaotic world‚Äù of the economy once it happens, but due to the market's abundant capital, resulting in the financial sector is still ‚Äúprosperity‚Äù, corporate surpluses are expected to grow by double digits, and optimistic about the performance of the stock markets in Taiwan and the U.S. in 2025, with the Taiwanese stock market expecting to see double-digit growth. In addition, the stock market performance of Taiwan and the U.S. in 2025 is optimistic, with Taiwan's stock market expected to see double-digit growth, and the index is expected to break through 25,000 points next year to reach a new high.  Fan Zhenhong, General Manager of Quni Investment Consulting, predicts that the biggest external variables in 2025 will be Trade War 2.0 and Trump 2.0, and TSMC (2330) will still lead the attack throughout the year. Quni's team predicts that the target price of TSMC in 2025 will be NT$1,380, which translates into the annual high of the weighted index to challenge 26,500 points, with the possible time point falling in Q1 or Q4, and the low point falling in the annual line position of 21,500 points. Point annual position, but in TSMC, ETF, ‚Äútwo guardian of the state‚Äù support, judgment to occur again in July this year, the chances of a sharp fall is not high, if really due to profit-taking selling pressure welling up, ‚ÄúTrump adviser‚Äù surprise speech and other shortcomings and heavy setbacks, it will be a good buy to enter the layout of the market, and optimistic about self-driving car-related, AI and robotics and other related concepts.

name: Michael Li
position: Technical Director, Qraft Technologies Hong Kong Limited
text: In order to enhance the transaction opportunities of intraday zero-share trading, from today (2), the aggregation interval has been shortened from 1 minute to 5 seconds, and the zero-share buying orders have also increased significantly, of which the zero-share turnover of TSMC exceeded 23% of the previous trading day in just half an hour after the opening of the trading session.  Looking at today's performance of the Taiwan stock market, benefited from the AI theme led by technology stocks tampering rise, TSMC (2330) in the early morning session smoothly returned to $ 1,000, the intraday price of $ 1,030, an increase of about 3.41%, in which the zero-share turnover in the opening of the trading session of only half an hour to 240,209 shares, has reached the last trading day 10,383,346 shares of the 23.13%, apparently zero-share trading summary interval shortened to produce the effect.   It is understood that the Taiwan Stock Exchange in October 2020 launched the ‚Äúintraday zero stock trading system‚Äù, as of the end of October this year, zero stock trading daily average turnover amounted to 2.968 billion, more than 50% of the concentration of the Taiwan 50 constituent stocks. Overall, the number of trading accounts has increased significantly, with the investment community under the age of 30 experiencing the greatest growth, accounting for approximately 28% of the total.  The FSC has previously indicated that it expects that the shortening of the intraday zero-share aggregation time to 5 seconds will promote intraday zero-share liquidity and increase the number of opportunities to invest in intraday zero-share transactions. However, the FSC also reminded investors that they should still carefully assess the transaction costs and their own financial strength, and should also understand the company's financial and business fundamentals and pay attention to the related investment risks.

name: Cassandra Sejour
text: As the US continues its heavy-handed restrictions on Chinese semiconductors, some manufacturers are finally losing their grip. China's domestic Arm server CPU design company ‚ÄúGuangdong Hongjun Microelectronics‚Äù is rumored to lay off 50% of its staff, the reason for which is rumored to be directly related to TSMC's supply cut-off.  Comprehensive mainland media ‚ÄúElectronic Engineering Album‚Äù, ‚ÄúcnBeta‚Äù reports, Hongjun Microelectronics plans to lay off all departments, not only part of the department's layoff ratio is quite high, the company's 300 people will also have 150 people lose their jobs. The reason for its large-scale layoffs, it is believed that with TSMC on November 11 supply cut-off can not be unrelated. Huawei was found in October, AI processor Ascend (Ascend) 910B using TSMC-made chips, in violation of the U.S. chip ban, TSMC has been cut off from November 11, China's supply of 7nm and more advanced chips. Now, the rumors of layoffs and insufficient funds to continue R&D and market competition indicate that China's semiconductor industry is facing a serious challenge.  Established in 2021, Hongjun Microelectronics has a registered capital of more than RMB 24.09 million (about NT$100 million). The founder, Shen Rong, has more than 20 years of experience at Intel, and was involved in the research and development of x86-based servers to replace the RISC-based servers, while the chief technology officer, Chen Weixiang, was the former chief architect of the Pentium internal core.

name: ANNY Y.
position: Semiconductor Distributor | Workwear Supplier | Startupper | Runner
text: hashtag #Intel's board gave CEO Pat Gelsinger the option to retire or be removed due to concerns over the progress of his ambitious turnaround plan, which sought to restore the company to its former leadership in the industry. Despite Gelsinger's efforts to reinvigorate Intel with large investments in manufacturing and technology, the company struggled with delays in its chip production timeline, losing ground to competitors like TSMC and AMD. These challenges, combined with the growing pressure from investors for faster results and improved financial performance, led the board to reassess Gelsinger‚Äôs leadership. His plan, though bold, faced significant execution hurdles, and ultimately, Intel's board needed to determine whether a change in leadership would better position the company for future success.  Intel‚Äôs recent self-rescue efforts over the past few months can be distilled into three key strategies: -Burden reduction  -External assistance -Pie-in-the-sky ambitions  Despite these efforts, Intel‚Äôs self-rescue measures have been met with mixed results. The foundry business is still far from turning around, and the company's competitive position in the semiconductor market remains fragile. Intel‚Äôs delays in advancing its process nodes, especially compared to TSMC, are worrying. The new Arizona wafer factory, which was supposed to come online in 2025, is also facing delays, further complicating Intel‚Äôs ability to meet its 18A goals. Moreover, Intel‚Äôs product performance has been underwhelming, with its new Core Ultra 200 series processors failing to generate the expected market excitement.  Intel‚Äôs efforts to capitalize on the AI boom have not yet paid off either. Despite Gelsinger's optimism about Intel‚Äôs AI roadmap, market realities tell a different story. The company‚Äôs Gaudi chips, which were touted as a major growth driver, have underperformed. Sales expectations for the Gaudi series have been slashed, and shipments of the upcoming Gaudi 3 chip are expected to be reduced by at least 30% in 2025.  Intel‚Äôs road to recovery remains long and uncertain. The company‚Äôs ambitious plans, from the 18A process to AI-driven products, are still in their infancy, and the challenges they face in execution are significant. While Intel has made progress in reducing costs and seeking external help, it remains to be seen whether these measures will be enough to restore the company to its former glory. The real test will come when the 18A process is put into mass production and when Intel‚Äôs AI products are tested in the marketplace. For now, investors and industry watchers are holding their breath, hoping that Intel can turn things around‚Äîbut the road ahead is anything but clear. text: Imagine a single thread so delicate yet so powerful that it could unravel the entire tapestry of modern technology.  This isn't science fiction. This is the hidden story of TSMC‚Äîa Taiwanese manufacturer quietly holding the world's digital future in its hands.  Semiconductors aren't just chips. They're the invisible architecture of our connected reality, smaller than a virus yet more intricate than our most complex machines.  Picture 15 billion transistors‚Äîeach one barely wider than a strand of human hair‚Äîcompressed into the device you're reading this on right now. Manufactured by a company founded by a very smart man.  But herein lies the risk.  This extraordinary ecosystem balances on a razor's edge as the China-Taiwan geopolitical tension could transform these microscopic marvels from technological miracles into global vulnerability.  And according to US intelligence, it could all kick off by 2027.  Our latest Deep Dive doesn't just explore a risk. It unveils a hidden narrative where technology, politics, and human ambition converge in ways you've never imagined.  The future isn't just being built. It's being calculated, one nanometre at a time.  Discover the story behind the story. Because understanding isn't just knowledge. It's power.

name: Erudite Asia
text: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., Ltd.'s stock market is weak after falling. Xie Jinhe: Semiconductors have reached a critical moment  TSMC's stock price is struggling, recently trading around 1,000 yuan after a drop to 992 yuan. Xie Jinhe, chairman of Xinhua Media, links this decline to former President Trump's claims about American technology theft, contributing to the broader downturn in the Taiwan stock market. He identifies three main challenges for TSMC and the Taiwanese semiconductor sector: Trump's statements, competitive pressures from China's mature processes, and a decline in demand from China.  In November, TSMC's stock fell by 44 yuan, from 1,090 to 992 yuan. Xie emphasized that the semiconductor industry is at a critical juncture, with Taiwanese companies facing not just fundamental issues but also uncertainties from Trump's variable stance and competition from China. Other firms like UMC and AMD are already feeling the pressure, with UMC's stock dropping by 9.55% in November.  Xie warns that losing the edge in mature processes would significantly impact TSMC, which is already seeing price reductions in its mature process products. The previously high demand from China has diminished, leading to a decline in stock prices for global semiconductor equipment manufacturers, including ASML and Applied Materials. This trend indicates substantial challenges ahead for TSMC in a difficult market environment.    Want more analysis of major developments in AI, semiconductors, and cloud computing in Asia? name: Pablo Andr√©s Muquillaza Cabrera
position: Vanguard in Technology and Innovation - Drives Positioning, Growth and Adds Value to the Company
text: La estrategia IDM 2.0 de Intel, presentada en marzo de 2021 por el CEO Pat Gelsinger, representa una evoluci√≥n significativa en el modelo de fabricaci√≥n de dispositivos integrados de la compa√±√≠a. Esta estrategia se basa en tres pilares fundamentales:  1. Red interna de fabricaci√≥n global: Intel contin√∫a fabricando la mayor√≠a de sus productos internamente, aprovechando su red de f√°bricas para optimizar productos, mejorar la econom√≠a y garantizar la resiliencia en la cadena de suministro.   2. Colaboraci√≥n con fabricantes externos: La empresa ha incrementado el uso de capacidad de fundici√≥n de terceros para ciertos productos, lo que le proporciona flexibilidad y escalabilidad en su producci√≥n.   3. Servicios de manufactura de Intel (Intel Foundry Services): Intel ha establecido una unidad de negocio independiente para ofrecer servicios de fabricaci√≥n a terceros, con el objetivo de convertirse en un proveedor clave de capacidad de manufactura en Estados Unidos y Europa.    Esta estrategia busca fortalecer la posici√≥n de Intel en la industria de semiconductores, permiti√©ndole competir m√°s eficazmente con l√≠deres del sector como TSMC. Sin embargo, la implementaci√≥n de IDM 2.0 ha enfrentado desaf√≠os financieros y operativos. En agosto de 2024, se inform√≥ que Intel estaba luchando por igualar la capacidad de producci√≥n de chips de √∫ltima generaci√≥n de TSMC, enfrentando dificultades financieras que podr√≠an obligarla a reconsiderar su estrategia.  A pesar de estos obst√°culos, Intel ha continuado avanzando en su hoja de ruta tecnol√≥gica. En octubre de 2024, la compa√±√≠a lanz√≥ la familia de procesadores Intel Core Ultra 200S, conocida como "Arrow Lake", que incorpora inteligencia artificial para mejorar la experiencia de gaming.  En resumen, la estrategia IDM 2.0 de Intel representa un esfuerzo integral para revitalizar su liderazgo en la industria de semiconductores, combinando fabricaci√≥n interna, colaboraci√≥n con terceros y la oferta de servicios de manufactura a clientes externos. Aunque ha enfrentado desaf√≠os en su implementaci√≥n, la compa√±√≠a contin√∫a innovando y adapt√°ndose a las demandas del mercado.

name: Deep Majumdar
text: Patrick Gelsinger is out! What's Next for the US chip company?   Full story on>>  üíª Intel's CEO finally departs after a 30-plus year run and a 3-plus year stint as CEO.  üíª Gelsinger was given the option to step down or be removed after the board lost confidence in his plans to turn around the American chipmaking icon, Bloomberg reported.  üíª, Chief Financial Officer and, EVP, Client Computing will take up the mantle of interim co-chief executives following Gelsinger‚Äôs retirement, Intel stated in a press release. Frank Yeary, independent chair of the board of Intel will serve as Interim Executive Chair.  üíª Intel‚Äôs Foundry Dilemma And Its AI Woes  Artificial intelligence computing is a sector that cost Intel billions in revenue. This money that could have gone to Intel‚Äôs data centre business was instead taken by Nvidia which turned its GPUs into essential components of AI computing.  üíª Gelsinger‚Äôs plan to explore avenues beyond personal computing and server processors such as making chips for other companies, a.k.a., its foundry business was unprecedented.  üíª While companies like Qualcomm and MediaTek chose to outsource their chip needs, Intel looked inward. It put the American tech giant in a head-to-head battle with companies like Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC).  üíª The Intel Foundry has been on a promising growth curve and roadmap but it needed a "big reset" in terms of leadership. With Gelsinger gone, the new CEO needs to approach AI chip innovation more aggressively.  üíª Arm Wrestling: Is Intel Losing?  The uprising of Arm-based processors is not a new story. Arm chips have been in the play for quite some time now. Cut to 2024 and we have all of the major OEMs in personal computing implementing Arm chips in their notebooks. Leading this list is Apple Silicon followed by Qualcomm‚Äôs Snapdragon X Elite.  üíª Currently, while Arm-based PCs control about 18 per cent of the notebook market, this number is projected to reach 40 per cent by 2025 as more Windows on Arm AI PCs are available. Meanwhile, Intel commands over 70 per cent of the x86 notebook market which is slowly slipping away.  üíª What‚Äôs Next For Intel: 18A To The Rescue?  Intel is banking heavily on the 18A to attract customers and boost revenue. Not that it already isn‚Äôt contributing to Intel‚Äôs growth. Intel has already gotten contracts from the US Department of Defense, Boeing, AWS and Microsoft. Plus, a push for AI chip innovation and advanced chip packaging will be key.  Intel's future success in AI will depend on whether its new CEO takes a more aggressive approach to AI innovations.  ‚úç Insights from||||  |||

text: Intel Strengthens Leadership Amid CEO Transition: A Strategic Move for the Future  This week, Intel made a significant leadership move by saying goodbye to CEO, leaving the company in search of a new chief. However, rather than waiting passively, Intel is proactively strengthening its leadership bench by adding two seasoned executives to its board of directors: Eric Meurice, the former CEO of ASML, and Steve Sanghi, the interim CEO of Microchip Technology.  Both new board members bring an immense wealth of semiconductor manufacturing experience, which Intel needs as it continues to navigate the rapidly evolving tech landscape. Meurice's expertise from ASML, a company central to the production of cutting-edge semiconductor equipment, and Sanghi‚Äôs leadership in microchip technology at Microchip Technology will offer Intel critical insights as it drives forward innovation in semiconductor design and manufacturing.  This strategic shift is a strong signal that Intel is not only focused on finding a new CEO but is also committed to reinforcing its leadership in the semiconductor space. With Intel‚Äôs ambition to lead in advanced chip technology, having executives with deep operational experience in this sector is vital. In a broader context, this move is a reminder of the importance of resilient leadership in times of transition.  Similarly, in Canada, companies in the tech and manufacturing sectors are also recognizing the value of enhancing leadership diversity and expertise to navigate technological advancements. Companies like and have increasingly turned to seasoned professionals from the tech industry to fill critical roles, ensuring they stay ahead in an ever-changing market.  This shift in Intel‚Äôs leadership could well set a precedent for how major corporations in North America address leadership transitions. As businesses face new challenges whether in technology, supply chains, or global competition, the ability to rapidly adjust leadership to meet these challenges is becoming a critical success factor.  What are your thoughts on Intel‚Äôs leadership strategy? How important do you think it is for companies to diversify and strengthen their leadership teams during CEO transitions? I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts. let‚Äôs keep the conversation going.

name: Jeffrey Cooper
position: Technology Author, Blogger, & Consultant | ex-Sourcing Lead at ASML | ex-Director Supply Chain at ABB | ex-Finance Mgr. at GE
text: He Was Going to Save Intel. He Destroyed $150 Billion of Value Instead.  Pat Gelsinger was one of the chip pioneer‚Äôs true believers. After his rescue strategy failed, the board lost confidence in him. How does this iconic American company survive?  Pat Gelsinger‚Äôs tenure as Intel‚Äôs CEO was marked by bold ambitions to revitalize the semiconductor giant through his IDM 2.0 strategy, a $20 billion investment in U.S. chip manufacturing, and championing the 2022 Chips Act. Despite his efforts to transform Intel into a leading contract chipmaker to compete with TSMC and Samsung, the company struggled with cultural inertia, a lack of competitive customers, and slower-than-expected advancements in chip technology. Under Gelsinger‚Äôs leadership, Intel lost $150 billion in market value and faced its largest quarterly loss of $16.6 billion, ultimately leading to his departure. The question looms: Will Intel split its design and manufacturing operations, undoing Gelsinger‚Äôs vision entirely?  My Take  Pat Gelsinger‚Äôs story is a masterclass in the challenges of corporate transformation at scale. While his vision of reintegrating design and manufacturing could have future merit, it highlights the importance of aligning bold strategies with cultural adaptability and operational execution. As AI reshapes the chip industry, Intel‚Äôs ability to pivot and partner effectively will hold the key to its next chapter.     Link to article:   Credit: Wall Street Journal  Get Ahead with the Latest Tech Insights! Explore my blog:

position: Director - Tax, Transfer pricing at Alvarez & Marsal
text: 18A was supposed to reach volume production by Q4 2024. Arrow Lake and Lunar Lake are being fabricated on TSMC‚Äôs N6/N3 nodes (depending on the tile), since Intel torpedoed its 20A node. With 18A yields at only 10%, things aren‚Äôt looking great - IFS really needs to get its act together, because at this rate, a fire sale or merger seems increasingly plausible.  Meanwhile, things appear to be going swimmingly for TSMC - Q4 2024 revenue is estimated to grow 30% vs. Q4 2023. Their N2 node (albeit slightly delayed) should enter volume production by Q4 2025, and it‚Äôs safe to say that the A19s and M5s of the world will likely utilize TSMC‚Äôs N3P node. However, I wouldn‚Äôt hold my breath for A18/M4-level performance or performance-per-watt gains next year!

name: Adaobi L Aghasili
position: Legal Compliance Counsel- Group Export Controls and Sanctions at Philips
text: üåê New BIS Export Control Updates: Key Changes Effective December 2024  On December 2, 2024, the Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) issued an Interim Final Rule introducing new Foreign Direct Product (FDP) rules and refining export controls on advanced computing items, supercomputers, and semiconductor manufacturing equipment. These changes are designed to enhance national security and export compliance frameworks.  Here are the highlights:  üìå New FDP Rules:  Advanced-node ICs tied to Footnote 5 (FN5) Entity List parties now require licenses.  Foreign-produced semiconductor manufacturing equipment (SME) linked to Country Group D:5 destinations or Macau also faces new controls.  üìå No De Minimis Threshold: For U.S.-origin content destined for FN5 entities or restricted locations under the SME FDP.  üìå License Exception RFF: Supports exports to fabrication facilities not engaged in advanced-node IC production.  üìå Expanded Controlled Items: High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) with bandwidth density >2 GB/s/mm¬≤ (ECCN 3A090.c).  Additions to the Commerce Control List (e.g., ECCNs 3B993, 3B994, 3D992).  üìå Compliance Resources:  8 new Red Flags to guide due diligence.  Clarifications on controls for software keys and advanced manufacturing technology.  While the rule is effective immediately, several provisions, including HBM controls and new FDP rules, have a compliance deadline of December 31, 2024.  Link:  üí° For more details, visit the BIS website or consult your compliance team.

text: NXP to Build a Chinese Chip Supply Chain for Its Customers  Dutch semiconductor maker NXP announced plans to build a Chinese chip supply chain for its customers, as U.S. restrictions on semiconductor exports to China tighten. With China being the largest market for electric vehicles and telecommunications, this move aims to safeguard access to a critical market.  NXP, a global leader in designing and manufacturing high-performance hybrid analog and digital chips for industrial applications, is widely recognized for its innovations in electronics, mobile payments, smart homes, and high-security chip solutions.  In recent developments, NXP is in talks with TSMC to expand their $7.8 billion Singapore joint venture, recognizing the importance of diversifying chip production in light of escalating U.S.-China tech tensions. VSMC, a joint venture formed by VIS and NXP in September 2024, held a groundbreaking ceremony for a 12-inch wafer factory in Tampines, Singapore, on Dec. 4, with plans for mass production to begin in 2027.  As a key player in the global semiconductor industry, NXP has built a strong foundation in automotive electronics, IoT, embedded security, and connectivity. In response to rapid technological advancements and shifting market demands, NXP has reinforced its market position through ongoing R&D investments, strategic acquisitions, and global partnerships. The company's strategic focus remains on delivering secure, intelligent, and connected solutions to meet growing global demand for efficient and reliable semiconductor products.  NXP's main competitors include: Infineon: Competes directly with NXP in automotive electronics, power management solutions, and security chips.  STMicroelectronics: A strong rival in , sensors, embedded processors, and power semiconductors.  Texas Instruments: Significant overlap with NXP in the market for analog chips and embedded processors. Renesas: Competes with NXP in automotive microcontrollers and power management solutions. Qualcomm: Challenges NXP in mobile communications and IoT technologies. Bosch: A key competitor in the automotive electronics market, particularly in areas like vehicle control and automation. name: Marco Mezger
position: Industrial / Specialty Memory, Storage & Semiconductor Expert
text: What  hashtag #Intel CEO Gelsinger's exit means for  hashtag #TSMC and  hashtag #Samsung hashtag #Chip giant caught between 'American hero' dream and chip industry realities üí°  has parted ways with CEO, but does that mean it will also part with its contract chipmaking ambitions?  Gelsinger, an industry veteran, was brought back to Intel in 2021 to make the company an American chip hero again. Three years later, he left it with a bleeding balance sheet, some gigantic yet unfinished production facilities and a business at a crossroads.  There are signs that Intel is not as committed to pursuing Gelsinger's IDM 2.0 strategy now that he is gone. That strategy was a road map for turning Intel into both a leading chip designer as well as a major contract chipmaker, or foundry, capable of rivaling(Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.) andof . IDM stands for "integrated device manufacturer."  Thanks again toandfor the full article with more background and insights via the link below üí°üôèüëá

name: Francis Benistant
position: Executive Director at Technology Modeling Automation
text: hashtag #semiconductor  hashtag #IDM  hashtag #Foundry  hashtag #intelcorporation  hashtag #boardofdirectors  hashtag #corporategovernance  hashtag #processingtechnology  hashtag #armprocessors  hashtag #x86architecture   The author gives an extensive analysis of Intel's decline which is accurate - except for the Foundry business. The author thinks that Intel shoudl focus on IFS and not on X86 architecture. While only China could build up a Foundry competing with TSMC, the time has passed for the US and UE.  Intel's Board of Directors: A Catalyst for Decline  This paper provides a comprehensive examination of Intel's leadership issues, strategic missteps, and eroding market position.  ‚Ä¢ Board incompetence: 7 of 11 members lack relevant semiconductor experience ‚Ä¢ Cultural shift: From engineering focus to business-oriented management ‚Ä¢ Process technology failures: 10nm node debacle allowed competitors to gain market share ‚Ä¢ Erosion of x86 dominance: Rise of Arm-based processors in client and server markets  The authors trace Intel's problems to the appointment of Paul Otellini as CEO, marking a shift from technical leadership to business-oriented management. This change led to a cultural transformation that prioritized political power over technical excellence.  Intel's failure in developing its 10nm process node is identified as a critical turning point, enabling competitors like TSMC and AMD to gain significant market share. The paper also discusses the erosion of Intel's x86 moat in both client and server markets, with Arm-based processors and accelerated computing solutions posing significant threats.  The analysis extends to Intel's financial decisions, criticizing the focus on stock buybacks over capital expenditures during Bob Swan's tenure as CEO. This approach is described as malpractice in a capital-intensive industry when the company was losing market share and lagging in process technology.  The paper argues that Intel's board has made a series of poor decisions, culminating in the dismissal of Pat Gelsinger and a renewed focus on x86 products. The authors contend that this strategy is misguided and unlikely to address Intel's fundamental challenges.  Limitations of the study include potential bias in assessing board decisions and a focus on internal factors without fully exploring external market dynamics. The analysis may also underestimate the challenges faced by Arm-based processors in fully displacing x86 in certain markets.  This comprehensive analysis provides valuable insights into the challenges faced by established technology companies in maintaining market leadership and the critical role of board decisions in shaping a company's trajectory.

name: Francis Benistant
position: Executive Director at Technology Modeling Automation
text: hashtag #CMOS  hashtag #transistors  hashtag #FinFET  hashtag #GAAFET  hashtag #5nmnode  hashtag #devicephysics  hashtag #integratedcircuits  hashtag #nanoelectronics  hashtag #chipdesign  hashtag #VLSI  hashtag #SOC  hashtag #microelectronics  hashtag #TCAD  hashtag   This study compares, using TCAD, FinFETs (PFFETs) and gate-all-around FETs (GAAFETs) at the 5nm CMOS technology node, challenging assumptions about future transistor designs. It explains why TSMC was right to push the FF until 3nm and not to move to GAA too early like SEC has done.  The research uses 3D numerical simulations to analyze and compare the performance of PFFETs and GAAFETs for high-performance (HP) and low-operation-power (LOP) applications. Results show comparable integration densities based on 6T-SRAM cell layouts for both device types.  For HP applications, PFFETs and GAAFETs demonstrate similar drive currents and intrinsic delays. In LOP scenarios, GAAFETs initially outperform PFFETs, but optimizing the PFFET's effective channel length can enhance its competitiveness.  Key innovations:  ‚Ä¢ Design of a pragmatic FinFET with simplified processing ‚Ä¢ Comparison of PFFET and GAAFET performance at 5nm node ‚Ä¢ Analysis of integration density using 6T-SRAM layouts ‚Ä¢ Optimization of G-S/D underlap for PFFET performance  The study addresses the challenge of continued CMOS scaling, questioning the presumption that GAAFETs will necessarily replace FinFETs at advanced nodes. It explores the tradeoffs between device performance and processing complexity.  Limitations include simplifications in the simulations and the extent of the benchmark. The study focuses on Si-based devices and does not extensively explore alternative materials or more complex GAAFET designs.  The findings suggest that PFFETs may be a viable and potentially preferable alternative to GAAFETs for future nanoscale CMOS technology, considering the balance between performance and processing complexity.

name: Aakhya India
text: India‚Äôs semiconductor consumption is projected to increase from $22 billion in 2019 to $110 billion by 2030.This could in turn mean that India would account for about 10% of global semiconductor demand. That is why building a strong semiconductor ecosystem is both an economic goal and a strategic need. While India is great at designing chips, setting up advanced manufacturing for semiconductors is still a challenge.  India‚Äôs success in chip design comes from its skilled workforce and strong IT sector. Global companies like Intel, Qualcomm, AMD and Broadcom have set up research centers across the country, using its talent to design complex chips for various uses. This shows the nation‚Äôs potential to play a bigger role in the global semiconductor market.  To fix its manufacturing gap, the India Semiconductor Mission (ISM) in 2021, offering financial help to promote semiconductor production. It is also working with global leaders such as Taiwan‚Äôs TSMC and the U.S.-based Synopsys to gain knowledge and build manufacturing facilities. India‚Äôs progress in building its own semiconductor system can be seen in new fab units being set up. Tata Semiconductor is building a plant in Assam, expected to be ready by mid-2025. In Gujarat, Tata Electronics and Taiwan‚Äôs PSMC are making two factories, with one expected to start production in 2026.  This will reduce its need to import chips and ensure a steady supply for important industries. It will also boost India‚Äôs position in the global semiconductor market, especially in uncertain times. Supporting this optimism, Jensen Huang, the CEO of NVIDIA, has publicly stated that "This is India‚Äôs moment." When a global tech leader of such stature bets on India, it signals a pivotal opportunity that Indians and the world cannot ignore.  India‚Äôs journey in semiconductors is full of promise. Its strength in chip design provides a good start, but moving into manufacturing will need to overcome challenges. With smart investments, international partnerships, and supportive policies, there is optimism that India can become a global leader in semiconductors.

name: Daniel Lee
text: Japanese government supports semiconductor and artificial intelligence (AI) industries  The Japanese government recently announced that it will invest more than 10 trillion yen (about 65 billion U.S. dollars) in the next decade to support the semiconductor and AI industries, with the goal of promoting cutting-edge technology and enhancing international competitiveness. Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said that this move is expected to drive more than 50 trillion yen in public and private investment, narrowing the gap with the world's major chip countries. Previously, Japan has set up a special fund of 4 trillion yen for the domestic chip industry, including 920 billion yen in support for Rapidus, which plans to mass-produce advanced logic chips in 2027. The new funds will further expand the scope of support and strengthen Japan's competitiveness in the global semiconductor and AI fields. This strategy echoes the large-scale chip investment plans of the United States and other countries, demonstrating Japan's determination to maintain its leading position in the global technology competition.

name: Enrico Cau, PhD
text: TAIPEI (Taiwan News) ‚Äî Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company's overseas expansion led to a record number of Taiwanese working in the US in 2023, according to the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) on Thursday. The number of Taiwanese working abroad reached a four-year high of 621,000 in 2023. A record 128,000 were employed in the US, per CNA. DGBAS Deputy Director Tan Wen-ling (Ë≠öÊñáÁé≤) linked this rise to TSMC's upcoming fabs in Arizona and the company's global expansion. This has driven a surge in Taiwanese workers in the US and Japan. Between 2009 and 2019, the number of Taiwanese working abroad grew from 662,000 to 739,000. The US-China trade war, technological disputes, supply chain restructuring, and COVID-19-related travel restrictions caused a drop in overseas employment, reaching a low of 319,000 in 2021. As the pandemic's impact waned, the number of Taiwanese working overseas rebounded in 2022 and 2023. It reached 621,000 in 2023, a year-on-year increase of 148,000, although still below pre-pandemic levels. While China remained the leading destination with 217,000 Taiwanese workers in 2023, its share dropped to 35%, down from 62.2% in 2011. This was due to factors like rising production costs and the return of Taiwanese businesses, Tan said.

name: Boluwatife Adekola
text: Today we will be exploring a vital concept abbreviated PDKs meaning,PROCESS DESIGN KITS.... Hmm where do we go from here?ü§îüòÉ  Alright,now imagine you want to design a microchip. To do that, you need a guide to make sure your design can actually be built by a semiconductor factory (foundry). A Process Design Kit (PDK) is that guide.  A Process Design Kit (PDK) is like a guide for designing microchips. It includes design rules, models for how components behave electrically, and tools to check if a design can be made into a real chip. It helps ensure that the design will be manufacturable.  For the process node (like 5nm or 7nm),it refers to the size of the features on the chip. Smaller nodes allow more transistors, improving performance and power efficiency. However, each semiconductor company (e.g., TSMC, Intel, Samsung) has its own way of making chips, even for the same node size. This means that each company provides a different PDK, customized to their specific technology, materials, and performance goals. For example, one company may focus on mobile devices while another targets high-performance computing.  The rise of open access PDKs is changing the game. These are free and available to anyone, which allows smaller companies, universities, and even hobbyists to design chips without high costs. A good example is the Google-SkyWater 130nm PDK, which opened chip design to the public. This has made chip design more accessible and encouraged innovation by letting more people experiment with and create their own chips.  In short, PDKs are essential for chip design, and open access PDKs are making it easier and cheaper for a wider range of people to get involved in semiconductor development.  What do you think about PDKs? Let's meet at the comment section üëá
